title: Gareth Southgate needs to revert to three at the back
text:

England's defeat by Czech Republic angered me.

We have started looking like a team who think we can just turn up and win games, but we can’t – not with the defence the way it is.

That’s back-to-back games now, including the 5-3 victory against Kosovo, in which we have conceded really poor goals.

And if Kosovo and Czech Republic can do that to us then I’m worried one of the big boys might really give us a pummelling.

We haven’t been amazing for a few games now. We have ridden our luck and been bailed out by some fantastic attacking play.

Our forward unit on any given day is 8/10 or 9/10 because Harry Kane guarantees goals, Raheem Sterling guarantees creativity and goals, and with Tammy Abraham and Callum Wilson, we have a very good pool of strikers.

(Image: PA)

Throw in our attack-minded midfielders and we have quality in abundance going forward.

That’s pretty much where we’ve done the damage recently and because of that we have been getting away with it, arguably since the World Cup.

The midfield remains a bit of a concern ­because the one thing England haven’t had is a player who can start on the halfway line, go past two or three opponents and turn defence quickly into attack. It remains to be seen if Leicester City’s James Maddison can be that man, and I’m not going to judge Mason Mount on Friday. Mount was asked to play as a No.10 and that’s not where he plays for Chelsea.

He could ­develop into the role but he reminds me of his club boss Frank Lampard during his playing days, someone who arrives in the right place at the right time rather than someone who will pick the ball up and waltz through a team like Paul Gascoigne. The midfield, therefore, is a 7/10 – not bad, but with room for improvement. The ­defence, however, is the issue. Only a ­tactical shift to three central ­defenders and wing-backs will resolve it.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: Getty Images)

If Liverpool, as champions of Europe and with arguably the best defence in world football, have a back five including Alisson, when fit, that is 9/10, England’s is a 5.5 or 6.

Harry Maguire didn’t automatically become world class when Manchester United paid £80million for him. He’s a very good defender but not great.

Goalkeeper Jordan Pickford needs to talk more, and be more ­dominant in his area.

We also need to get the right personnel around them, too.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

(Image: REUTERS)

And that means ­acknowledging we are not as good defensively as we think we are. It is why, in Bulgaria ­on Monday, I would like to see Gareth Southgate revert to a system with three centre-backs, one he practised when he first took over.

Bulgaria showed us at Wembley that they are not a good side, but we need to get used to the playing the system for when we take on stronger opponents.

So I would start with: Pickford, Trent Alexander-Arnold, Joe Gomez, Maguire, Tyrone Mings, Ben Chilwell, Ross Barkley, Jordan Henderson, Mount, Sterling and Kane. And if we sort it out the formation won’t be far off.

If we leave it as it is, though, then we could have the same outcome as Friday, or worse when we face France, Italy, Spain or Germany.

Even against poorer teams, we have had spells when they have looked like they can score.

Most European teams, whether it be Croatia in the World Cup semis or Kosovo and Czech Republic, tend to have 10 or 15 minutes in a game where they dovetail in a way we just don’t and that needs fixing as well.

We need to make sure we’re solid enough to cope with those periods and in Prague we showed we aren’t.

Czech Republic aren’t winning the Euros or the World Cup anytime, and neither are we unless we can overcome it.
description: England suffered their first qualifying defeat for 10 years when they lost to Czech Republic on Friday night
